message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe headache with vomiting and neck stiffness suggests a possible subarachnoid hemorrhage. CT scan of the head without contrast is the initial study of choice in patients suspected of having a subarachnoid hemorrhage as it can rapidly detect the presence of blood in the subarachnoid space. Lumbar puncture can help confirm a diagnosis, but it should not be performed until CT scan has been done. MRI scan of the brain and CT angiography of the head are not first-line studies for suspected subarachnoid hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is a medical emergency. CT scan of the head without contrast is the most appropriate next step in the management of the patient because it can quickly identify a ruptured aneurysm or bleeding in the brain. Lumbar puncture is contraindicated until a CT scan is obtained. MRI and CT angiography may be ordered after the CT scan if needed for further evaluation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including the sudden onset of severe headache, neck pain, and vomiting, are suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage. CT scan of the head without contrast is the recommended first step in management to rule out hemorrhage. Lumbar puncture may be indicated if the CT scan is negative but suspicion for subarachnoid hemorrhage remains high. MRI scan and CT angiography are not typically used as first-line diagnostic tools for suspected subarachnoid hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a subarachnoid hemorrhage, and CT scan of the head without contrast is the most appropriate first imaging study to confirm the diagnosis. Lumbar puncture, MRI scan, and CT angiography may be done later, depending on the results of the initial CT scan.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset, severity of pain, radiation to the neck, and vomiting suggest a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). CT scan without contrast is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient to confirm the diagnosis of SAH. Lumbar puncture is contraindicated before a CT scan to avoid herniation through a ruptured aneurysm. MRI scan and CT angiography are not first-line diagnostic tests for SAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of a severe headache with vomiting, neck pain, and a previous episode suggests subarachnoid hemorrhage. CT scan of the head without contrast is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient to confirm or rule out a subarachnoid hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which can be diagnosed by a CT scan of the head without contrast. Lumbar puncture can confirm the diagnosis, but it should not be performed until a CT scan is done to exclude the possibility of a mass lesion. MRI and CT angiography are not the initial diagnostic tests in the evaluation of a suspected subarachnoid hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which can be confirmed with a CT scan of the head without contrast. Lumbar puncture may be done as the second diagnostic test if the CT scan is negative, but not as the first choice. MRI and CT angiography may be used in some cases but are not the initial diagnostic test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible subarachnoid hemorrhage, such as sudden onset headache, neck stiffness, and vomiting. A non-contrast CT scan is the most sensitive imaging study to evaluate for a subarachnoid hemorrhage. Lumbar puncture is indicated if CT scan doesn’t reveal any abnormalities but patient is still suspected of having a subarachnoid hemorrhage. MRI and CT angiography are not the first-line diagnostic tests for subarachnoid hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a subarachnoid hemorrhage, and a non-contrast CT scan of the head is the most sensitive imaging study to diagnose this condition. Lumbar puncture may be considered if the CT scan is negative, but it is risky due to the increased risk of herniation in the presence of a clot. MRI may be considered later, but it is not as sensitive as CT for diagnosing subarachnoid hemorrhage. CT angiography may be considered if an aneurysm is suspected, but non-contrast CT is the first step in diagnosis.
